var_fa_ann.Notes: In 542 Chinese hyperlipidemia patients, baseline serum ALT and AST (markers of hepatic function) were significantly higher in SLCO1B1 388AA homozygotes than in 388AG or 388GG carriers. In a dominant model (AA vs AG+GG), adjusted β for ALT was 6.137±2.939 U/L (P=0.037) and for AST was 5.253±1.667 U/L (P=0.002). Logistic regression using ALT≥40 U/L vs <40 U/L showed adjusted OR for carrying the 388G allele (AG or GG) in the abnormal ALT group was 0.4 (95% CI 0.2–0.9; P=0.018); for AST≥40 U/L vs <40 U/L the adjusted OR for 388G carriers was 0.5 (95% CI 0.2–1.0; P=0.038). Joint-analysis (Table 5) showed that subjects with 388AA and 521TT had significantly higher ALT (adjusted β 2.628±0.766; P=0.001) and AST (adjusted β 2.03±0.592; P=0.001) compared with carriers of 388G and/or 521C alleles.
var_fa_ann.Sentence: rs2306283 (SLCO1B1 388A>G) Is Associated with increased activity of SLCO1B1 when assayed with plasma markers of hepatic function as compared to the 388G allele (AG or GG genotypes), with 388AA homozygotes showing significantly higher baseline ALT and AST levels.
Citations: Individuals with the 388AA genotype had higher ALT and AST levels than those with the 388AG or 388GG genotypes (P = .037 and P = .002, respectively).

In a dominant model, the average ALT and AST levels were significantly higher in patients with the homozygous 388AA than in those with the 388AG or 388GG genotypes in both the unadjusted and the adjusted models.

As shown in Table 4, we divided all patients into 2 subgroups based on baseline ALT and AST critical values. … Compared to participants in the normal subgroup of baseline ALT levels, the adjusted odds of carrying the 388G allele (388AG or 388GG genotype) among the participants in the abnormal subgroup was 0.4 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.2-0.9). Similarly, compared to the participants in the normal subgroup of baseline AST levels, the adjusted odds of carrying the 388G allele (388AG or 388GG genotype) among the participants in the abnormal subgroup was 0.5 (95% CI, 0.2-1.0).

var_fa_ann.Notes: In joint genotype analysis (Table 5), patients carrying both SLCO1B1 388AA and 521TT genotypes (interpreted as having the 388A/521T haplotype) had significantly higher baseline ALT and AST levels compared with carriers of the 388G and/or 521C alleles. For ALT, adjusted β for 388AA+521TT vs 388G and/or 521C carriers was 2.628±0.766 U/L (P=0.001); for AST, adjusted β was 2.03±0.592 U/L (P=0.001). Haplotype analysis (Table 6) showed that individuals in the abnormal ALT group (ALT≥40 U/L) had a higher frequency of the 388A/521T haplotype (0.35 vs 0.27; P=0.038) and a lower frequency of the 388G/521T haplotype (0.54 vs 0.62; P=0.04) than those in the normal ALT group; similar differences were observed when stratified by AST.
var_fa_ann.Sentence: The SLCO1B1 haplotype 388A/521T (rs2306283;rs4149056) Is Associated with increased activity of SLCO1B1 when assayed with plasma markers of hepatic function, with carriers of the 388AA and 521TT genotypes showing significantly higher baseline ALT and AST levels as compared to carriers of 388G and/or 521C alleles.
var_fa_ann.Assay type: clinical plasma enzyme measurements (ALT, AST) with haplotype/joint genotype analysis
Citations: Moreover, we divided all patients into normal and abnormal subgroups based on elevated ALT and AST values (≥ 40 U/L), participants in the abnormal subgroup had a higher frequency of the 388A/521T haplotype and a lower frequency of the 388G/521T haplotype compared to those in the normal subgroup.

As shown in Table 5, we found that, compared with the 388G and 521C allele carriers, the patients with the 388AA and 521TT genotypes had significantly higher concentrations of ALT and AST. After adjusting for important covariates, including BMI, age, alcohol consumption, and smoking, the result remained significant.

As shown in Table 6, when comparing between the dichotomized ALT and AST groups, the results of haplotype analysis indicated that participants in the abnormal subgroup had a higher frequency of the 388A/521 T and a lower frequency of the 388G/521 T in comparison with those in the normal subgroup.

summary:
Study question and design:
- Prospective cohort of 542 Chinese adults with primary hyperlipidemia treated with simvastatin 20 mg once daily for 8 weeks after a 7–10 day washout.
- Aim: evaluate whether two common SLCO1B1 variants, 388A>G (rs2306283) and 521T>C (rs4149056), and their haplotypes are associated with (1) baseline liver function (ALT, AST), (2) baseline lipids, and (3) short-term lipid-lowering response to simvastatin.

Genotyping and measurements:
- SLCO1B1 388A>G and 521T>C genotyped by PCR–RFLP.
- Fasting ALT, AST, TG, TC, LDL-C, HDL-C measured at baseline, week 4, and week 8.
- Minor allele frequencies: 388G = 0.28, 521C = 0.11; both SNPs in Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium.

Key pharmacogenomic findings – hepatic function:
1) 388A>G and baseline ALT/AST
- 388AA homozygotes had significantly higher mean ALT and AST than 388AG/GG carriers.
  • Dominant model (AA vs AG+GG), adjusted for age, BMI, alcohol, smoking:
    - ALT: AA higher by ~6.1 U/L (P = 0.037).
    - AST: AA higher by ~5.3 U/L (P = 0.002).
- When ALT and AST were dichotomized at ≥ 40 U/L:
  • Those in the abnormal ALT group (≥ 40 U/L) were significantly less likely to carry the 388G allele (AG or GG): adjusted OR for AG+GG vs AA = 0.4 (95% CI 0.2–0.9), consistent with AA being enriched among patients with elevated ALT.
  • Similar pattern for AST: adjusted OR for AG+GG vs AA = 0.5 (95% CI 0.2–1.0).
- Interpretation: the 388A allele, particularly in AA homozygotes, is associated with higher liver enzymes, while the G allele appears protective against ALT/AST elevation in this hyperlipidemic Chinese cohort.

2) 521T>C alone and baseline liver tests
- No significant association between 521T>C genotypes and baseline ALT or AST in unadjusted or adjusted models.

3) 388A>G × 521T>C interaction
- Joint analysis (reference = carriers of 388G and 521C [GG/AG + CC/TC]):
  • Patients with 388AA + 521TT had significantly higher ALT and AST than reference, even after adjustment:
    - ALT: β ≈ +2.6 U/L (P = 0.001).
    - AST: β ≈ +2.0 U/L (P = 0.001).
- Suggests a gene–gene interaction where the combination of 388AA and 521TT confers the highest liver enzyme levels.

4) Haplotype analysis (388A>G–521T>C) and liver enzymes
- SNPs in strong LD (D′ = 0.882).
- Compared normal vs abnormal ALT or AST groups:
  • The “high-enzyme” groups (ALT ≥ 40 or AST ≥ 40 U/L) had:
    - Higher frequency of 388A/521T (roughly 35–36% vs 26–27%; P ≈ 0.04 and 0.007).
    - Lower frequency of 388G/521T (≈ 54% vs 62%; P ≈ 0.04 and 0.032).
  • 388G/521C (haplotype *15) frequencies were similar between groups.
- Interpretation: haplotype 388A/521T is enriched in patients with elevated ALT/AST, while haplotype 388G/521T is relatively protective.

Key pharmacogenomic findings – baseline lipids:
- 388A>G:
  • After multivariable adjustment, 388AA carriers had modestly but significantly higher baseline HDL-C than AG/GG combined (β ≈ +0.14 mmol/L; P = 0.049).
  • No significant differences for baseline TC, LDL-C, or TG by 388A>G genotype.
- 521T>C:
  • No significant association with baseline lipid parameters (data not shown in detail).

Key pharmacogenomic findings – simvastatin response:
- All subjects received simvastatin 20 mg/day.
- After 4 weeks:
  • Participants carrying the 388G allele with 521TT genotype had greater TC and LDL-C reductions than those with 388G plus 521C (TC and LDL-C reductions significantly larger; details in Supplemental Table 3).
  • This is consistent with functional data:
    - 388G increases OATP1B1 transport activity, fostering hepatic uptake of statin.
    - 521C reduces OATP1B1 activity, associated with higher circulating drug but paradoxically less LDL-C lowering in some studies.
  • Thus, the “high-activity” combination (388G + 521TT) appears to confer stronger early lipid-lowering response to simvastatin.
- After 8 weeks:
  • No significant differences in lipid-lowering effect by either SNP or their haplotypes.
  • Echoes other reports (pravastatin, simvastatin) where early genotype-dependent differences attenuate over longer treatment duration.

Safety / CK findings:
- CK increased overall after 4 and 8 weeks of simvastatin.
- No significant association of 388A>G or 521T>C with CK elevations in this cohort (supplemental data), in contrast to some Western data linking 521C to myopathy.

Authors’ mechanistic interpretation:
- OATP1B1 transports bile acids and influences hepatic lipid handling.
- 388AA–521TT and haplotype 388A/521T may lead to higher bile acid levels and enhanced fatty acid absorption, potentially promoting hepatic steatosis and ALT/AST elevation.
- 388G/521T may reduce bile acid levels, decrease hepatic fatty acid uptake, and protect against fatty liver–associated aminotransferase elevation.
- For statin efficacy, increased OATP1B1 transport (388G with intact 521T) promotes hepatic uptake of simvastatin, enhancing LDL-C lowering early in therapy.

Limitations noted by authors:
- No assessment of fatty liver status (imaging or biopsy); cannot directly link genotypes → steatosis → ALT/AST.
- Bile acid levels were not measured; mechanistic interpretation is inferential.
- Modest sample, particularly few 521CC homozygotes, limiting power.

Clinical pharmacogenomic implications:
- In Chinese hyperlipidemic patients, SLCO1B1 388A>G and 521T>C variants and their haplotypes are associated with:
  • Baseline ALT/AST: 388AA and haplotype 388A/521T linked to higher enzymes; 388G/521T appears protective.
  • Baseline HDL-C: 388AA associated with slightly higher HDL-C.
  • Early (4-week) lipid response to simvastatin: greater TC and LDL-C reduction in 388G + 521TT carriers vs 521C carriers; effect not sustained at 8 weeks.
- These data support a role for SLCO1B1 genotyping (beyond the well-known 521T>C myopathy risk allele) in predicting liver enzyme profile and short-term simvastatin response in East Asian populations, but replication and integration with hepatic imaging and bile acid phenotyping are needed before routine clinical implementation.

Title:"Associations of the SLCO1B1 Polymorphisms With Hepatic Function, Baseline Lipid Levels, and Lipid-lowering Response to Simvastatin in Patients With Hyperlipidemia"

PMID: 30336686

PMCID: PMC6714829
title: Associations of the SLCO1B1 Polymorphisms With Hepatic Function, Baseline Lipid Levels, and Lipid-lowering Response to Simvastatin in Patients With Hyperlipidemia

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Patients with the SLCO1B1 388AA genotype had significantly higher baseline ALT levels than those with 388AG or 388GG genotypes (dominant model AA vs AG+GG, adjusted β=6.137, P=0.037).
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: rs2306283 Is Associated with increased likelihood of PK:Alanine aminotransferase level in people with Disease:Hyperlipidemia.
Citations: In a dominant model, the average ALT and AST levels were significantly higher in patients with the homozygous 388AA than in those with the 388AG or 388GG genotypes in both the unadjusted and the adjusted models.

Compared to participants in the normal subgroup of baseline ALT levels, the adjusted odds of carrying the 388G allele (388AG or 388GG genotype) among the participants in the abnormal subgroup was 0.4 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.2-0.9).

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Patients with the SLCO1B1 388AA genotype had significantly higher baseline AST levels than those with 388AG or 388GG genotypes (dominant model AA vs AG+GG, adjusted β=5.253, P=0.002).
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: rs2306283 Is Associated with increased likelihood of PK:Aspartate aminotransferase level in people with Disease:Hyperlipidemia.
Citations: Multiple linear regression analysis results were shown in Table 3. In a dominant model, the average ALT and AST levels were significantly higher in patients with the homozygous 388AA than in those with the 388AG or 388GG genotypes in both the unadjusted and the adjusted models.

In conclusion, our study revealed that the SLCO1B1 polymorphisms were related with ALT and AST concentrations and could further influence the efficacy of simvastatin treatment. In clinical practice, identifying genetic variants or haplotypes may be helpful to predict the concentrations of ALT and AST and to guide individualized therapy in patients with hyperlipidemia.

var_pheno_ann.Notes: After adjustment, average HDL-C level was significantly higher in patients with the 388AA genotype than in those with 388AG or 388GG (AA vs AG+GG, β=0.143, P=0.049).

Citations: Multiple linear regression analysis results were shown in Table 3. In a dominant model, the average ALT and AST levels were significantly higher in patients with the homozygous 388AA than in those with the 388AG or 388GG genotypes in both the unadjusted and the adjusted models. After adjustment for important covariates, including age, body mass index (BMI), alcohol consumption, and smoking, the average HDL-C level was significantly higher in patients with the 388AA genotype than in those with the 388AG or 388GG genotypes (*P* = .049).
Our results suggested that the average HDL-C levels were significantly higher in patients with the 388AA genotype than in those with the 388AG and 388GG genotypes (*P* = .049).
